title: What will be the closing price of natural gas (per MMBtu) on 1 June 2021, according to Bloomberg?
preds: FWIW: Futures prices continued to rise today. https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html

Court decisions in the Netherlands and Australia may have disproportionately affected this question and the price of Natural Gas NG1 as an equivalent to petroleum products:
https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/eight-kids-nun-may-have-doomed-coals-future-russell-2021-05-31/ https://seekingalpha.com/article/4432056-royal-dutch-shell-options-after-court-order-to-reduce-emissions-by-45-percent
https://www.reuters.com/business/legal/big-oil-may-get-more-climate-lawsuits-after-shell-ruling-lawyers-activists-2021-05-28/
https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/05/27/royal-dutch-shell-netherlands-hague-court-oil-fossil-fuels-climate-change/

..Will make a price final forecast guess tomorrow.  https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html https://www.naturalgasintel.com/july-natural-gas-futures-rally-to-close-out-volatile-week-cash-prices-cruise/
Wow, a 6-month challenge and it literally goes right down to the wire on the last day.  Funny how these things happen.
Futures are right at $2.99 on Bloomberg currently (6:05 CST).  Right on the border! Adjusting some. Starting to feel like a roulette wheel.

NG price currently bouncing over $3 despite a higher-than-expected injection into storage. FWIW the price trend in recent days generally charts upward. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/NG1:COM https://www.naturalgasintel.com/weather-outlook-moves-hotter-as-natural-gas-futures-recover-losses-early/ https://finance.yahoo.com/news/natural-gas-price-fundamental-daily-132354104.html
Futures prices are right on the border this morning,  edging up over $3.02 in the night and bouncing around at the open today near $3 (Bloomberg).
Minor adjustment up given Monday’s closing price.
FWIW, June futures price has recently lowered some. https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html
Current futures trading down and 5 days left.  Adjusting bets some.  Just hoping I’m not clobbered by a large tail move.
Updating based on the end of week results.  EIA May 20th weekly report shows dry production increasing, partly due to more rigs coming online.  Still hedging some on the high side.
Minor adjustment.  This could be an interesting toss up if it drifts above $3 again.
Will the price hold above $3.00 for the next two weeks?  The crowd thinks not, but is hedging that bet.  For me it's a coin toss, but I won't go too far against the crowd.
Right over the border line, supposedly due to bulls preparing for summer cooling demand in the Northeast. https://www.naturalgasintel.com/
Oops.  Forgot to enter the updated probabilities.
Updated based on this week's data.  Trading close to $3 but hasn't crossed.  Increasing the $3 to $3.5 bucket probability to reflect.
It does seem the futures are very much in range as summer looms the price is lock in a narrow range that can be around the $3 range so it can a few cents higher or lower.

As on 12 May 2021, NG price per MMbtu is USD 2.94. 
According to EIA forecasts, due to flat production and exports, the price would be USD 3.14 in 2021.
https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/natural-gas/030921-us-eia-lifts-forecasts-for-2021-22-natural-gas-and-power-consumption
Hence, in my opinion, as on 01 June it would be app. USD 3.00
Updated with Monday's market results + SPGroup aggregation
Updated 4cast with 4/30 market futures price, then aggregated with selected peers
Expect to increase electrical power consumption, this should increase demand of natural gas, therefore prices may be looking at north.

"Old man winter" in large parts of the U.S., setting new temperature low records for this day in multiple places.
However,
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DHHNGSP
Adjusting on the higher end after today future prices

LNG storage is up YOY but still below forecast.  Spring weather patterns have produced an increase in Gas Weather Degree Days (GWDD) in the north/mid western area of the US.  Despite these factors, price volatility appears to be in a relatively tight range.  Hard to know where the eventual spot price will wiggle out.  Updating my forecast based on this and consolidating most chips on the $2 to $3 range now.
Reran 4Cast using ETS and last few days of data.  Then aggregated with Peer Group Team
Quick aggregation update using prior, new 4cast with last week+ of data, and selected peers

Not changing my forecast today, but it's worth noting this week; - AL Shabaab and rebels are threatening the delivery of a French gas project in northern Mozambique (1)
- $4.7B (AUD) gas field announced by Santos off the northern Australian coast (2) Mozambique news is likely to push price up if not resolved soon. Australian news unlikely to have impact in the next 3 months as production is scheduled to begin in 2025. 1. https://apnews.com/article/tanzania-islamic-state-group-mozambique-e2132716341c076706ef1ce8ccceac2c
2. https://www.msn.com/en-au/money/markets/santos-and-partners-investing-2447-billion-to-develop-barossa-offshore-gas-field-near-darwin/ar-BB1f8te4

With a little over 2 months left, and with the price sitting very close to a boundary between buckets, it could go either way.  When it comes to short-term price movements of commodities, with the exception of professional traders, we have to acknowledge what we don't know.  So we're just guessing here -- I'll put the odds at very close to a coin toss.
Reran forecast and aggregated using my previous forecast as the prior
Recent downtrend has increased the uncertainty some, the result for me are widened tails of my 4Cast distribution
Futures have price at about $2.75 for June.   https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/future/ng.1
Coming to this one a bit late.  Forecast out using log transformed prices + Winter's Method.
Raising forecast somewhat for the $3-plus option in case the current cold weather problems have longer-term ramifications. https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html
Currently, the Nor'easter with more than a foot of snow is driving prices - for the near- to medium term.
Spreading out my chips.  I tend to over concentrate, especially in the early stages of a challenge.  I think it's due to over confidence.  Must ... resist!

Unless you can predict the weather in the Northern Hemisphere you can't predict the outcome.  The link to futures prices provided below by @jayb is a probably a better predictor than anything I could conjure up.

Maintaining forecast for now. May and June '21 gas futures prices remain above $2.50 right now. (https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html) FWIW (links): Even some experts seem to believe that NG prices are difficult to predict: https://www.forbes.com/sites/judeclemente/2021/01/24/a-mild-winter-continues-low-us-natural-gas-prices/?sh=75052054456d https://oilprice.com/Energy/Natural-Gas/Whats-Next-For-Very-Volatile-Natural-Gas-Markets.html
Natural gas reduce consumption during summer, but may increase demand to industry dynamics.

I should have looked back further at this, prices below $2 were only a thing for several months this year, before that it was rare so dropping the likelihood of that possibility. Leaning toward a return to prices below $2.50 as pandemic gets more under control by then.

NG futures prices are currently in a $2.54 to 2.68 range out to June 2021. (https://futures.tradingcharts.com/marketquotes/NG.html, https://www.barchart.com/futures/quotes/NG*0/profile) One analysis: https://www.naturalgasintel.com/natural-gas-futures-rally-early-in-the-new-year-as-analysts-expecting-bright-2021-for-bulls/

According to this article the rise in prices is largely due to a reduction in supply thanks to the pandemic. Apparently much of the natural gas production is in association with oil, and oil production has dropped with oil prices. Based on that I think there's a good chance that this could revert to the original trend somewhat by June, meaning lower prices. https://www.forbes.com/sites/thebakersinstitute/2020/11/10/why-have-us-natural-gas-prices-increased-post-covid/?sh=342c6fb13958

Over last 9 years, comparison of June prices with previous December : 
-> June prices have been higher than previous December 4 out of 9 times.
-> Only once they were higher by more than 15%
-> In 3 years they were higher by maximum of 6.1%
-> Rest of the time they were lower than December (average 5% below December prices). In December 2020 the average price is $2.61. Baseline probability of prices crossing $3.00 is 11%. Month	2010	2011	2012	2013	2014	2015	2016	2017	2018	2019	2020	Total
June		4.52	2.50	3.81	4.59	2.77	2.62	2.99	2.94	2.33	1.70	3.07
December	4.25	3.25	3.44	4.28	3.51	2.05	3.59	2.78	3.93	2.29	2.61	3.23
June prices compared to previous December			-23.2%	18.1%	6.1%	-18.6%	2.0%	-9.8%	1.9%	-34.0%	-21.1%	-4.8%
Initial forecast -- following the crowd, but with a bias towards a higher price.
..Slight forecast re-adjustment based upon this additional information: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-08/-widowmaker-natural-gas-trade-collapses-on-warm-fall-weather

-- For reference, the 52-week NG1 price range is currently $2.37- 3.51, with a 50-day simple moving average price of about $2.80. (https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/NG1:COM, https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/NG%3DF/chart?p=NG%3DF) -- "Although EIA still expects prices to increase in the coming months because of rising space heating demand and rising U.S. liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports amid declining U.S. natural gas production, the lower January price forecast reflects higher forecast storage levels this winter compared with last month's forecast. EIA expects that monthly average spot prices will average $3.01/MMBtu in 2021, which is up from the forecast average of $2.07/MMBtu for 2020." (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/natgas.php, https://www.marketwatch.com/story/eia-lifts-2020-2021-forecasts-for-oil-prices-but-cuts-the-outlook-for-natural-gas-2020-12-08) -- "EIA expects production to begin rising in the second quarter of 2021 in response to higher natural gas and crude oil prices." (https://www.fxempire.com/forecasts/article/natural-gas-price-prediction-prices-rise-led-by-lower-production-forecast-688101) -- Economic recovery tied to COVID-19 mitigation will likely be a key factor for this question -- https://longforecast.com/natural-gas-forecast-2017-2018-2019 ..Giving a little extra weight in this initial forecast to the cited EIA 2021 predictions.
natural gas price go down in the summer months

I see four main determinants of the NG price next summer: /political will in the U.S. to reduce carbon emissions in the medium term will restrict investment into new drills for NG, all the more the current relatively low price indicates that the US are already well-supplied for domestic use. /NG fired power plants, which will consume a low double digit percentage share of the NG total consumption, could be crowded out by the production of electricity of renewable energy plant, which could be increasing yoy and prioritized in the grid. As the NG plants are the most flexible and versatile of all kinds, they are supposed to be the first to be quickly dimmed or shut down in times of plenty supply of solar or wind energy, and there's probably regulation that forces them to in order to safeguard grid stability. From that perspective, NG power plants will increasingly shift from being part of the base load into a back up, as soon as summer will arrive. As this question ends 01 June 2021 and near the annual maximum of solar energy production and usage, the info will send pricing signals to other linked energy markets, so that this question is probably closely intertwined with this
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1840-will-the-u-s-consume-more-energy-from-renewable-sources-in-may-2021-than-it-did-in-may-2019-according-to-the-u-s-energy-information-administration-eia Moreover, as the cost of production per MWh for e.g. solar power rapidly sinks on an annual basis, the breakeven point for gas usage (the point at which additional demand will fade in) compared to renewable energy sources of electricity, expressed in the spot price of Natural Gas will also be lowered incrementally, and profitability running gas power plants will be reached at ever lower spot prices. /the U.S. attempt to stop the Russian pipeline project "Nordstream2" in the Baltic Sea, which is highly controversial within the EU between e.g. Eastern European nations and Germany, does not appear to be successful in the end. The bulk of the hefty investment has been made, the pipeline is almost completed except from a few kilometers, and the Russian part of the syndicate is determined to go on whatever it takes. Threats of the US to single out Germany as a culprit and sanction municipalities, companies, individuals and politicians rather caused disgruntlement, annoyance, incomprehension and resistance towards the US position among Germans involved.
To cut a long story short, the likelihood is low and the hope maybe never materializes that in the near future the EU can function as a flourishing export market and an outlet for an excess production of (liquefied) NG, which will cause an excess supply on the domestic markets unless the supply is quickly limited (intentionally or by bankruptcies in the shale gas industry), since after almost one year of pandemic and reduced economic activity the subterranean cavern stores will be solidly filled. /the spot price of NG is heavily seasonal and thus correlates closely to the question how cold and long the winter season and the heating period will be, and how large a share of the US geographically will be that has an extended period of a snowy cold winter 2020/21. 
(i) In case the winter fuels a depletion of inventories, the price may spike to 4.00USD/MMBtu or more in February.
(ii) In case the winter remains warm and mild, as it may be expected once in a few years in the wake of climate change, the price may peak at 3.00 to 3.50USD already. The following seasonal price decline will then critically depend on where it started at its peak.
2.00USD or less on 01 June 2021 would be a record low, but considering the factors above, there are three of them that point to this record, while only one of them - maybe - supports higher prices, from my point of view.
It is too soon to be determined, and there will likely not be a reliable indication of the final answer before mid-February 2021.
